title: How did the first humans keep their nails from overgrowing? - Quora

response.answer_text: By “first humans” we may mean deeper archaic humanity, still in the genus Homo. Which extends back some 2 million years or so. In which case we can only infer from animal and some anthropological studies, really, as nails, like hair, don’t often leave a fossil trace. At best we may get an impression, or we can interpret some bone attachment points as evidence for some sort of “use”. In that sense we probably “used” nails a lot more, as tools, or as stiffening and support for our fingers and toes when going about our daily business. So wear and tear was “natural”. We would have dug in our nails to peel fruits open, for example. And in a natural setting fruit was not domesticated, so skins were tougher. We also dug for starchy tubers, and a host of other “uses”, with or without other tools. Plus we had no shoes, of course, so just walking and running probably kept nails in check. If they got ragged, we probably bit them even again. It seems natural to do so, and other apes (and many modern humans) do that today. Unlike other clawed animals, we use our nails as support for softer tissue, to enhance fine grip and touch sensitivity. In the modern world we use what we have for pressing buttons or whatever, and don’t “use” them as we may have done in the deep past, or expose them to that sort of wear and tear. So we get a false impression of what they are, or how they may have grown and been “managed”.

When involved in a lot of physical activity, one will often notice that the fingernails readily tear a sliver off at the tip if they are even a little long. Nails are intended to break away before they get too long. Also, we hear about people who habitually bite their nails. I suspect that this is one instinctive activity one finds in other animals. After all, I have watched my cats quietly grooming their nails, snipping off little bits of the tips (You find them here and there on the floor. It’s one way cats use to keep their claws from getting too long.) I think it’s not much of a leap to say that humans bite their nails to keep them from getting too long also. The human body — keeping its nails short by instinct. Who knew? But most likely true.

Probably the same way we do today. Adam and the rest of the human race before the flood were much more advanced than we are today - they had perfect brains, better memory, and the lifespan of almost a millennium to invent and design their ideas. I’m sure that coming up with the concept of fingernail clippers was not a difficult thing for them to do. Within just the first 8 generations, they were experts in working with brass and iron (Gen. 4:22) - and there have been many pre-flood metal artifacts discovered buried in solid rock, that defy modern science’s ability to account for them.

Hi, Battum Emilla Q. How did the first humans keep their nails from overgrowing? A. The same way that other primates and animals do; natural wear. Many primates bite their nails. Some do not. It's not species specific. Chimpanzees, for example, usually bite their nails; some prefer to leave them alone. They do grow continuously and nails not kept trimmed probably break off (looking at the thickness of those nails, I get the impression that this might be rather painful if they break too short).

Well, of course they didn’t stop them from growing. that can’t be done. I’ve often asked the same question. The only answer I have is that they must have chewed on their nails to trim them. Hardly a good idea, but what alternative did they have—we don’t shed or nails like cats, and dogs nails will eventually get brittle and crack away from a new nail beneath—not very gracefully ,however.

Just as other animals keep their nails and claws from overgrowing—by heavy use. They use them for digging, climbing, husking tough fruits, cracking nuts, splitting apart wood and other plant stems, fighting—all manner of things that are pretty rough on nails. Just back from his manicure

The same way may of us still do: by biting them, and chewing them off. Strange to say, we don’t always need a cell phone, Google, or a specialist to help us do what we may need to do. Of course, at a later date those ancestors of ours had sharp tools of bone, slate, volcanic glass, etc., to help them keep their nails trim - as well as kill their evil neighbors…

Injuries and fungus would cause the nail to be misshaped. You should study the fingernails of chimpanzees and gorillas. Modern human nails are in the way. Pay attention to the fingernails of primitive people. Next time you go to need mechanical work or some skilled labor, study their fingernails. Gorillas to skilled labor, the nails are similar. Modern fingernails break and tear. Some primates have no fingernails.

I have been growing the nails on my right hand as built-in guitar picks for more than twenty years. I can vouch for the fact that they break off all the time from doing yard work, loading the tailgate, repairs, etc., etc. If I were a caveman, I be skeptical of anyone with long nails as that would show me how lazy they were!

Well I just bite mine off. They probably didn't have to though, because they used their hands a lot more for things like digging, pulling, scraping, etc. More or less the same way animals nails don't overgrow. I wonder more how say, middle ages people did it.

Thanks for the question, there were no Salons way back 200,000 years ago plus. You could imagine how much their hands were used for many processes, digging was a constant for food fossiking, and other things, preparation of food by hand, picking etc… Their nails would have worn down, or broken off, and the eye tooth would have been used for biting off straggled nails like we do today.
They may have used tree barks and sharpened them like cats. I’ve always said that nail biting is a carryover from when we were swinging from the trees, LOL.
Teeth. Depending on when you define “first humans”, there was probably a long phase where scrabbling at dirt, etc, kept them worn down.

Nails can sometimes be fossilised, anyway I’m not an expert in that matter. You can also look what happens with living relatives: see the quora question: Do apes and monkeys cut their nails? Biting seems to happen most.
Ever do a lot of manual labor? No worries, you do not need to trim your nails if you work with your hands on rough material.

How do primitive cultures today manage their nails? I would expect a daily life of hard labour would keep them sufficiently worn down. A sharp stone or abrasive surface would also suffice when necessary
